Improves logging in worker-executor (part of #173)

There seems to be a flakyness in the hot-update tests (possibly a race condition where calling `get_or_create_paused_pending`, something else activates the worker simultaneously). Not sure if it is introduced by this PR, likely has the same underlying cause as #534

candidates.title: Trying to speed up CI
candidates.body:
- Using https://github.com/Swatinem/rust-cache instead of custom set up
- Using https://github.com/mozilla/sccache/
- Tweaks to the cargo make file to make things faster
- Restructured CI job flow trying to maximize reuse of the cache
- 5 parallel worker executor test jobs
- Tried `cargo-hikari` but decided to not use it

candidates.title: Worker executor storage abstractions
candidates.body:
Resolves #288 

Introduces three storage types:
- key-value storage (also supporting storing sets and sorted sets) 
- indexed storage
- blob storage

The key-value storage and indexed storage has Redis and in-memory implementations, the blob storage has S3, in-memory and local file system based implementations.

This simplifies the code as individual services no longer have different implementations (for example `PromiseService` used to have a redis and an in-memory implementation now there is only a single one depending on key-value storage, etc)

All three storage interfaces get _namespaces_ which are fixed enums, and they can use it in different ways to determine how to implement data. For example in Redis it affects key prefixes, and whether to use hashed objects or not, but other implementations may use it to use different tables, or choose to just use it as part of a key.

Cleaned up key paths in redis a bit (no longer using `instance:` for example)

Changed how blob-storage is implemented: previously it was creating an S3 bucket for each "container" in the WASI blob-storage interface which is not very good because the number of buckets is limited in an AWS account and it also requires more rights than desirable. So right now the S3 blob storage implementation only requires two pre-configured buckets, one for compilation cache and one for user data where the logical structure is determined by key prefixes (account-id/container-name)

candidates.title: Idempotency key and exactly-once RPC
candidates.body:
Resolves #360 

- [x] Change terminology from `InvocationKey` to `IdempotencyKey`
- [x] Remove the `get-invocation-key` APIs, idempotency key is always generated by the caller
- [x] Make it possible to pass an optional idempotency key for both `invoke` and `invoke-and-await`
- [x] Removed the obsolete "JSON over Protobuf" invocation API which was only needed for the migration from Scala
- [x] Change the REST API to use idempotency headers instead
- [x] Change worker bridge to allow passing idempotency keys from the incoming headers and/or using explicit Rig expression
- [x] Generate a persistent idempotency key in the WASM RPC implementation before doing the invocation in order to make it exactly-once
- [x] Fix the "invocation key service" in worker executor base to be backed by a cached map of idempotency keys with pointers to the oplog for results, fully recoverable on startup from the oplog/metadata cache.
- [x] Remove the stdio-eventloop calling convention

candidates.title: Tests for the golem-rust library
candidates.body:
Resolves #167 

Also fixes issues with some old test components (broken by changes into golem-wit) and moves everything to wit-bindgen 0.17.0 (which was already the preferred version).

Note: 
- the new tests are in `transactions.rs` in the worker executor tests
- the new test component is called `golem-rust-tests`
- everything else is just fixed/rebuilt old test components

candidates.title: Worker Bridge Router
candidates.body:
closes https://github.com/golemcloud/golem/issues/315

- Introduces Router
   - Internally a `FxHashMap<http::Method, RadixNode<T>>`
- Introduces RadixNode
   - Implementation of a Radix Tree for an Http Router
   - Supports: 
      - Literal Paths: `api`
      - Variable Paths: `{worker-id}`
      - Catch all paths: `*`
- Router is used to validate incoming requests, and to validate that API Route Definitions are all unique during creation/update
> The paths `/worker/{worker-id}` and `/worker/{id}` would conflict, regardless of variable name, because they have the same structure

## Performance
The fastest map implementation that I tested was FxHashMap. Here's the comparison after changing it from VecMap. 

Two parameters are used in the latest benchmark
- `hit` is the hit rate
- `len` is the number of routes loaded into the tree

```shell
matches/len=10/hit=25   time:   [52.327 ns 52.882 ns 53.522 ns]                                  
                        change: [-17.705% -16.328% -15.036%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high severe
matches/len=20/hit=25   time:   [58.998 ns 59.434 ns 59.869 ns]                                  
                        change: [-19.565% -18.165% -16.963%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high mild
matches/len=50/hit=25   time:   [66.727 ns 67.267 ns 67.837 ns]                                  
                        change: [-17.955% -17.225% -16.383%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 4 outliers among 100 measurements (4.00%)
  3 (3.00%) high mild
  1 (1.00%) high severe
matches/len=100/hit=25  time:   [69.895 ns 70.637 ns 71.355 ns]                                   
                        change: [-21.483% -19.691% -18.186%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) low mild
matches/len=10/hit=50   time:   [55.228 ns 55.857 ns 56.491 ns]                                  
                        change: [-15.261% -14.226% -13.151%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high mild
matches/len=20/hit=50   time:   [61.549 ns 62.336 ns 63.355 ns]                                  
                        change: [-18.253% -17.287% -16.300%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 2 outliers among 100 measurements (2.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high mild
  1 (1.00%) high severe
matches/len=50/hit=50   time:   [68.583 ns 69.021 ns 69.456 ns]                                  
                        change: [-22.123% -21.335% -20.621%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 3 outliers among 100 measurements (3.00%)
  2 (2.00%) low mild
  1 (1.00%) high mild
matches/len=100/hit=50  time:   [72.845 ns 73.404 ns 74.065 ns]                                   
                        change: [-27.565% -25.900% -24.629%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 8 outliers among 100 measurements (8.00%)
  3 (3.00%) low mild
  3 (3.00%) high mild
  2 (2.00%) high severe
matches/len=10/hit=75   time:   [59.045 ns 60.482 ns 62.218 ns]                                  
                        change: [-12.785% -10.543% -7.8619%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 3 outliers among 100 measurements (3.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high mild
  2 (2.00%) high severe
matches/len=20/hit=75   time:   [65.270 ns 66.695 ns 68.463 ns]                                  
                        change: [-14.711% -13.262% -11.729%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 3 outliers among 100 measurements (3.00%)
  3 (3.00%) high severe
matches/len=50/hit=75   time:   [71.911 ns 72.447 ns 72.962 ns]                                  
                        change: [-22.867% -20.607% -19.000%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)

matches/len=100/hit=75  time:   [75.373 ns 75.710 ns 76.035 ns]

                        Performance has improved.
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high mild
```

## OLD Performance

The route tree uses a radix tree which compresses the tree and makes it faster to traverse than a normal trie.

Each node keeps a Vec of child nodes `Vec<(Pattern, RadixNode)>` in sorted order for static/literal paths. When searching for a literal node, we use binary search to make it more efficient. When checking a path, we will check all the static paths before checking if there is a variable path. 

This is faster than a `BTreeMap <Pattern, RadixNode>` in the benchmarks

We still need a way to cache these Routers, because for now they're being generated on every incoming request. They are not cheap to construct.

### BTreeMap (UNUSED)
```shell
matches/0/len=10        time:   [97.592 ns 99.020 ns 100.57 ns]                             
Found 4 outliers among 100 measurements (4.00%)
  4 (4.00%) high mild
matches/1/len=20        time:   [115.90 ns 117.24 ns 118.91 ns]                             
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high severe
matches/2/len=50        time:   [142.36 ns 143.79 ns 145.39 ns]                             
Found 2 outliers among 100 measurements (2.00%)
  1 (1.00%) low mild
  1 (1.00%) high severe
matches/3/len=100       time:   [158.92 ns 159.78 ns 160.68 ns]                              
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high severe
```

### Sorted Vec + Binary Search (USED)
```shell
matches/0/len=10        time:   [60.163 ns 61.361 ns 62.583 ns]                             
                        change: [-38.599% -37.484% -36.371%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
matches/1/len=20        time:   [67.535 ns 68.440 ns 69.303 ns]                             
                        change: [-42.160% -41.477% -40.789%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high mild
matches/2/len=50        time:   [78.137 ns 78.753 ns 79.358 ns]                             
                        change: [-45.887% -45.351% -44.864%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 2 outliers among 100 measurements (2.00%)
  1 (1.00%) low mild
  1 (1.00%) high mild
matches/3/len=100       time:   [85.419 ns 85.849 ns 86.285 ns]                              
                        change: [-47.168% -46.452% -45.929%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has improved.
Found 3 outliers among 100 measurements (3.00%)
  1 (1.00%) low mild
  2 (2.00%) high mild

```

## Performance (OLDEST)
> This benchmark uses [divan](https://github.com/nvzqz/divan) but the reports were sub-optimal and there was a lot of noise. I have since switched to criterion (first report is latest)

### BTreeMap

```shell
Timer precision: 41 ns
router                     fastest       │ slowest       │ median        │ mean          │ samples │ iters
├─ radix_tree_all_matches                │               │               │               │         │
│  ├─ 10                   94.85 ns      │ 219.8 ns      │ 102.8 ns      │ 103.7 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
│  ├─ 20                   109.6 ns      │ 305.6 ns      │ 119 ns        │ 120.4 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
│  ├─ 50                   139 ns        │ 405.3 ns      │ 152.4 ns      │ 154.2 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
│  ╰─ 100                  152.4 ns      │ 264.9 ns      │ 164.3 ns      │ 165.6 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
╰─ radix_tree_with_misses                │               │               │               │         │
   ├─ 10                   150 ns        │ 238.4 ns      │ 161.2 ns      │ 162.5 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
   ├─ 20                   152 ns        │ 267.9 ns      │ 162.8 ns      │ 163.9 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
   ├─ 50                   147.1 ns      │ 1.733 µs      │ 158.5 ns      │ 161.5 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
   ╰─ 100                  139.4 ns      │ 538.3 ns      │ 149.6 ns      │ 151.4 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
```

### Sorted Vec + Binary Search
Commit https://github.com/golemcloud/golem/pull/357/commits/b5bf93159951797a6c7265bd41a87d7f101f52bf
```shell
Timer precision: 41 ns
router                     fastest       │ slowest       │ median        │ mean          │ samples │ iters
├─ radix_tree_all_matches                │               │               │               │         │
│  ├─ 10                   88.73 ns      │ 146.7 ns      │ 94.65 ns      │ 95.28 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
│  ├─ 20                   86.94 ns      │ 190 ns        │ 92.27 ns      │ 92.96 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
│  ├─ 50                   109.5 ns      │ 2.104 µs      │ 115.7 ns      │ 116.9 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
│  ╰─ 100                  112.4 ns      │ 319.6 ns      │ 118.8 ns      │ 119.6 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
╰─ radix_tree_with_misses                │               │               │               │         │
   ├─ 10                   115.1 ns      │ 225.9 ns      │ 121.8 ns      │ 122.5 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
   ├─ 20                   116.4 ns      │ 1.842 µs      │ 122.6 ns      │ 123.7 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
   ├─ 50                   113.5 ns      │ 243.8 ns      │ 118.4 ns      │ 119.1 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
   ╰─ 100                  107.4 ns      │ 174.7 ns      │ 112.8 ns      │ 113.3 ns      │ 10000   │ 10000000
```

candidates.title: Support wave like syntax,
candidates.body:
Fixes #351 
Fixes #244 
Fixes #184 
Fixes #224 

Documentation on what's being done in progress:  https://www.notion.so/golemcloud/Worker-Bridge-Expression-Language-and-Recent-Developments-869c9b5d4a6d44f988d49adb500ce07b

The document will also cover some better explanation of the immediate tickets, since I feel some ticket details seem to be opaque.

### Main parts of the PR

* A complete revamp of read-write of `Expr`. Basically the syntax of `Expr` was up in the air until now  and now on it's `mostly` aligned with wasm-wave syntax.
   * A **new writer module** handling writing Expr back.  https://github.com/golemcloud/golem/blob/support_wave/golem-worker-service-base/src/expression/writer.rs. This is far more maintainable than what was before which was complicated code.
   * A **new text module** with `from_string` and `to_string` for `Expr`: https://github.com/golemcloud/golem/blob/support_wave/golem-worker-service-base/src/expression/text.rs
   * These modules are with in `expression` module
  
* A complete rewrite of **tests for `Expr`  read-write round-trips,** covering another ticket. I have tried to come up with a _pattern_ in tests and make our `Expr` far more reliable. Check them out: https://github.com/golemcloud/golem/blob/support_wave/golem-worker-service-base/src/expression/text.rs.  This spec covers all combinations of `Expr` within each type of `Expr` fixing numerous number of bugs. Tests are further divided into various modules `record_tests`, `sequence_tests`, `tuple_tests`, `flag_tests` etc.
  
* A complete revamp of `tokenizer` since we needed much more maintainable approach to handle complex usecases and parsing.  **Basically, `Cursor` is disappeared and `Tokeniser` is lazy**, with lots of new helper functions that helps with `Expr` parsing. https://github.com/golemcloud/golem/blob/support_wave/golem-worker-service-base/src/tokeniser/tokenizer.rs#L218

* A **new rules module** within tokenizer module. The opening-ending of tokens was all over the place before, killing time when trying to change code. Therefore introduced a `Rules` module within tokeniser to handle lookups that involves skipping nested tokens. Example: Find the position of the comma of the outer list in `[ [a, b], [c, d]]` or `({ flag1, flag2}, [ a, b], { a : b, c: d }]`. https://github.com/golemcloud/golem/blob/support_wave/golem-worker-service-base/src/tokeniser/token_start_end_rules.rs 

* And obviously the main part which is expr parsing supporting wasm wave syntax (as much as I can, but will continue to do some minor changes in further PRs). https://github.com/golemcloud/golem/tree/support_wave/golem-worker-service-base/src/parser/expr. Each types has its own module for parsing, and all of these modules have functions that follow a common pattern making it maintainable 


I know there are changes here, but there is none that is unimportant here, and that's why I am trying to write a document on what's being covered here.

candidates.title: Golem test framework
candidates.body:
Major refactoring involving the worker executor tests, integration and sharding tests, and the (not merged) benchmarking suite.

Introduces a base library for all tests and benchmarks, and rebases the existing test code to use it.

- Resolves #234
- Resolves #235 
- Resolves #236 
- Resolves #237 
- Resolves #327 

The primary motivation is to be able to use the same set of helper functions (test and benchmark DSL) for all layers of testing:
- worker executor tests (only running worker executor itself as a "libarary")
- integration tests (spawning multiple services, talking to them with gRPC)
- golem-cli tests 
- benchmarks (with the ability to set up and talk to remote infrastructure)

This is achieved by restructuring and unifying the existing code, having:

**test dependencies**

These are all the services (golem or third party) that are required for running the tests. Each has a couple of implementation, each implementation responsible for starting and stopping the dependency as well as being able to set up a communication channel to it, and to describe for other services how to access it (private / public host and IPs - private to be used "between dependencies", public to be used from the test runner)

**configurations**

There are three implementations of `TestDependencies`, each setting up them in different ways.

- `WorkerExecutorTestDependencies` only used for worker executor tests, and sets up the "fake", partial test dependency set that is enough to use the same DSL functions for worker executor tests as for the real integration tests
- `EnvBasedTestDependencies` makes decisions based on environment variables and should work the same as the previous test runners worked
- `CliTestDependencies` parses command line arguments and allows to configure all implementations of test dependencies (provided (already running), spawned (as native processes), docker, minikube and k8s-on-aws). This is intended to be used for benchmarks.

**DSL**
The current set of test functions work on any `TestDependencies`, and it is mostly copied from what prevously was the worker executor tests.
There is also a separate set of types and functions targeting benchmarks, with an initial capability of recording key-value pairs where value is either a duration or a count, calculating some statistics, etc.


**Key differences from the previous code:**
- The worker invocation test fuction now takes `wasm_rpc::Value`
- The K8s resource dropping is now reseted to the "drop each resource" implementation - this probably has to be changed back to drop a full namespace but I wanted to see if it works.
- I have dropped all `Result` propagation in the test code because I found that just panicking as early as possible provides a better test-debugging experience, and slightly simplifies the code
- The test dependency implementations are more separated than before - using `dyn` traits
- Avoided passing around the docker client lifetime (and had to because of the dyn traits) by assuming that for the tests, one global docker client is good enough.
- Had to change the minikube port forwarding implementation to work on non-linux too. Tried to keep the linux implementation as well but did not test it.

**Stability:**

- The sharding tests now contain the new "scripted" version as well as the previous random one. The random one is still flaky, probably because of the known sharding-manager issues. If it is annoyingly flaky we can ignore it but I don't want to compeltely delete it
- The benchmarks are now independent of the infrastructure setup in a way that they can be tested with fully local ("spawned" or "docker" modes). This works. However the minikube version fails for me for a weird reason (not being able to create the environment the _second_ time even though everything seems to be deleted).
- Did not test on real AWS infra, but the code is the same as in the previous benchmark PR so if that worked it should still work.

repo.description: Golem is an open source durable computing platform that makes it easy to build and deploy highly reliable distributed systems.
